Authors:
Wu Zhang, Zhibiao Nan, Pei Tian, Meijiao Hu, Zhaoyin Gao,
Ming Li, Guodao Liu
Title:
Microdochium paspali, a new species causing seashore paspalum
disease in south China
Keywords: pathogenic fungi, multigene phylogeny, tropical China
Abstract:
Seashore paspalum (Paspalum vaginatum) is a prostrate,
saline-tolerant, warm-season turf grass species that is widely used in
golf courses in tropical and subtropical regions. A new species of
Microdochium was identified as the causal agent of leaf blight, a novel
disease of this plant. In 2010, foliar necrosis and canopy thinning were
observed on 11 surveyed golf courses in Hainan Province, China,
especially on fairways and putting greens. The infected leaves initially
appeared to be water-soaked and dark green, but then leaves rapidly
faded to yellow or became chlorotic. The infected leaves rapidly died,
leading to a sparse appearance in infected areas, leading to the disease
name âsparse leaf patchâ. Isolates with rich and light pink to yellow
mycelia and salmon-coloured pionnotes were cultured from diseased turf
foliage. Pathogenicity was confirmed by inoculating these isolates onto
âSeasprayâ seashore paspalum. Phylogenetic analysis based on internal
transcribed spacer (ITS), translation elongation factor 1Î± (tef-1Î±)
and Î²-tubulin (BenA) sequence data indicated these isolates formed as a
distinct clade within Microdochium (Xylariales). Further microscopic
examination demonstrated that the species was morphologically distinct
from three similar species of Microdochium. The name Microdochium
paspali sp. nov. is proposed for this novel fungal pathogen.
